Award.AwardTitle: A Scaffolded Data-Centric Approach to Improved Learning of Introductory Computing Concepts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance and importance of this project is the availability of improved science for teaching fundamental computational concepts both to students pursuing degrees in computer science and to students where computation plays a secondary but increasingly vital role in the practice of their discipline. The fundamental problem addressed by this project is the limited methods currently available to motivate and sustain student engagement in challenging parts of the learning process. Through the use of relevant and authentic data combined with an improved learning environment the project will achieve improvements in learning and, more broadly, will provide the "data literacy" increasingly critical in the economy and society. While advantageous for all students, these characteristics of realism are especially engaging for students in under-represented populations. The "big data" resources are useful not only in introductory courses but also for emerging data science courses. The project will develop a deep understanding of the impact on student motivation and learning of the project's interventions across diverse student populations. This understanding will influence curriculum design and help shape better pedagogical practices.

The goal and scope of this project will be enhanced knowledge of, and extended technologies for, improving motivation and cognitive gains of students learning introductory computing concepts. The project will extend the catalog of available data sets, add authoring and curation tools enabling the efficient creation and restructuring of data sets, improve the ability of a student to search for a relevant data set, and provide scaffolding to allow early visualization of "big data". The project will extend a block-based visual programming environment, BlockPy, allowing mutual translation between Blockly and Python. The extension will add an instructor authoring tool and run-time support for immediate feedback on algorithm-based exercises that improves student learning and encourages student exploration of alternative algorithms. New visualizations will support student learning in any programming class using big data. These resources will be combined with other course elements in a robust web framework supporting many forms of distributed instructional delivery. The project will apply the Dick and Carey Instructional Design method to facilitate adoption by others and integrate detailed assessment of the curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a strong national need not only for students trained in computer science but also for students who can apply computational thinking skills in virtually every academic major and career path. This project developed new ideas, curriculum, and supporting technology to help confront the challenges faced by students in all academic majors in their early learning of computing. Four outcomes are notable. 

First, the project gave evidence that student motivation can be sustained by embedding their learning in the context of posing questions about the real world and answering these questions using authentic, authoritative data sets. The supporting technology is an infrastructure for creating such data sets, a collection of such data sets, and a programming environment that flattened the learning curve into more easily mastered progressive stages. 

Second, the project pioneered the development of a new style of feedback given to students when they made programming mistakes. The new style of feedback focused on misconceptions - incorrect or only partially correct ideas - that students developed during their learning of programming. The misconceptions were identified by tell-tale patterns in the students code. Giving feedback directed at the misconceptions whenever the pattern appeared was shown to accelerate students’ mastery of a key computational concept. The supporting technology created an open-ended environment for giving students feedback about misconceptions as well as other styles of feedback. A special language was developed to help instructors author feedback about patterns present in their students’ programs. 

Third, programming is difficult in part because it is a written static description of a dynamic process carried out by a computer. Interactive visualizations - graphical displays controlled by a student’s actions -  were developed to help students make the connection between the static and the dynamic aspects of a key computational idea. Studies showed that these interactive visualizations helped students make this connection in their early learning. Moreover, formally analyzed interviews of students showed deeply revealing insights into how the students used the interactive visualizations and other course resources. Contrary to what an instructor might anticipate, students developed their own “game plan” for how, when - or even whether - they used the various course resources. The analysis also showed that students learned by forming patterns of how to solve different problems. While these patterns were helpful they were also deeply problematic when students applied the pattern inappropriately.

Fourth, the project created a novel Computational Thinking curriculum that has been tested for several years with hundreds of students from a wide variety of academic majors and career goals. The curriculum blends all of the ideas and technologies developed in the project with pedagogical techniques for hands-on problem solving (active learning), learning in small groups (collaborative learning), encountering the same ideas with progressively greater depth (spiral learning), and demonstrating mastery through self-defined projects.

The curriculum and technologies are freely available.
